title: Live Agency Journey OS (Universal 360° Digital Marketing)

purpose.oneLine: A machine-readable, end-to-end agency operating journey that defines stages, handoffs, artifacts, roles, skills, and grounding sources.
whatThisIs: A workflow graph (nodes/edges) describing how an agency runs from intake → strategy → execution → reporting → learning.
A RACI-like ownership model describing who hands off to whom and what must be delivered.
A skills and grounding registry to keep outputs evidence-based and repeatable.

designPrinciples: Single Source of Truth (SSOT): if it isn't in SSOT, it didn't happen.
Artifacts-first: every step outputs a concrete artifact.
Supervisor-first: a single orchestrator controls pods; pods do not act without authorization.
Evidence-first: no causal claims without a test plan; attribution is directional unless incrementality is established.
Speed with safety: 7–14 day validation loops, with compliance gates when needed (especially clinics).
Ops reality: workflows reflect capacity constraints, response SLAs, and approvals.

skillsRegistry.purpose: Enumerate all repo skills so the supervisor can route/authorize pods and sub-skills deterministically.

glossary.SSOT: Single Source of Truth (task system + docs + asset store).
glossary.SLA: Service Level Agreement (e.g., response time for approvals or lead responses).
glossary.Pod: A specialized execution unit (Content, Creative, Paid, Analytics, etc.).
glossary.Supervisor: The single orchestrator agent/role that authorizes pods and owns decisions.
glossary.Artifact: A concrete deliverable: doc/spec/template/report that becomes the source of truth for a decision or handoff.

keySections.heading: First Principles
keySections.textPreview: Break problems down to basic truths and build solutions from there. Instead of copying competitors, ask "why" repeatedly to find root causes. Use the 5 Whys technique to tunnel down to what really matters.

keySections.heading: Jobs to Be Done
keySections.textPreview: People don't buy products—they "hire" them to get a job done. Focus on the outcome customers want, not features.

keySections.heading: Circle of Competence
keySections.textPreview: Know what you're good at and stay within it. Venture outside only with proper learning or expert help.

keySections.heading: Inversion
keySections.textPreview: Instead of asking "How do I succeed?", ask "What would guarantee failure?" Then avoid those things.

keySections.heading: Occam's Razor
keySections.textPreview: The simplest explanation is usually correct. Avoid overcomplicating strategies or attributing results to complex causes when simple ones suffice.

keySections.heading: Pareto Principle (80/20 Rule)
keySections.textPreview: Roughly 80% of results come from 20% of efforts. Identify and focus on the vital few.

bullets: Don't change the core message; focus on enhancing it
Multiple focused passes beat one unfocused review
Each edit should have a clear reason
Preserve the author's voice while improving clarity
keySections.textPreview: Good copy editing isn't about rewriting—it's about enhancing. Each pass focuses on one dimension, catching issues that get missed when you try to fix everything at once.

keySections.heading: The Seven Sweeps Framework
keySections.textPreview: Edit copy through seven sequential passes, each focusing on one dimension. After each sweep, loop back to check previous sweeps aren't compromised.

keySections.heading: Sweep 1: Clarity
bullets: Sentences trying to say too much
keySections.textPreview: **Focus:** Can the reader understand what you're saying?

keySections.heading: Sweep 2: Voice and Tone
bullets: Word choices that don't match the brand
keySections.textPreview: **Focus:** Is the copy consistent in how it sounds?

keySections.heading: Sweep 3: So What
bullets: Statements that don't connect to reader's life
keySections.textPreview: **Focus:** Does every claim answer "why should I care?"

keySections.heading: Sweep 4: Prove It
keySections.textPreview: **Focus:** Is every claim supported with evidence?

keySections.heading: Sweep 5: Specificity
bullets: Generic statements that could apply to anyone
Round numbers that feel made up
Missing details that would make it real
Adjectives doing the work nouns should do
keySections.textPreview: **Focus:** Is the copy concrete enough to be compelling?

keySections.heading: Sweep 6: Heightened Emotion
bullets: Pain points mentioned but not felt
keySections.textPreview: **Focus:** Does the copy make the reader feel something?

keySections.heading: Before Starting
keySections.textPreview: Gather this context (ask if not provided):

keySections.heading: 1. Program Type
bullets: Are you building a customer referral program, affiliate program, or both?
What's your current CAC from other channels?

keySections.heading: 2. Current State
bullets: Do you have an existing referral/affiliate program?
What's your current referral rate (% of customers who refer)?
Do you have customer NPS or satisfaction data?

keySections.heading: 3. Product Fit
bullets: Is your product shareable? (Does using it involve others?)
Does your product have network effects?
Do customers naturally talk about your product?

keySections.heading: 4. Resources
bullets: What tools/platforms do you use or consider?
What's your budget for referral incentives?
Do you have engineering resources for custom implementation?

bullets: Existing customers recommending to their network

keySections.heading: Affiliate Programs
bullets: Reaching audiences you don't have access to

bullets: Referral program for customers (simple, small rewards)
Affiliate program for partners (larger commissions, more structure)

protocol.goal: Prevent generic advice and enforce evidence-first decisions.

steps.name: Start from decisions, not data
steps.description: List the business decisions this workstream must support (budget shifts, offer changes, creative refresh, tracking definitions).

steps.name: Consult platform documentation
steps.description: Read policy and technical docs for GA4/GTM, Meta Ads, Google Ads, GBP, etc., before prescribing tactics.

steps.name: Competitive and market audit
steps.description: Audit 3–5 local competitors: offers, messaging, proof, creative formats, and GBP footprint.

steps.name: Benchmark expected performance
steps.description: Use category- and channel-appropriate benchmarks to set expectations and kill metrics.

steps.name: Establish internal baselines
steps.description: Capture last 30–90 days performance and operational constraints (capacity, response SLA).

steps.name: Synthesize into testable hypotheses
steps.description: Convert insights into 7–14 day experiments with explicit surfaces, kill metrics, and decision dates.
